title: 103_s1013
content: The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" is cited in this section, which focuses on amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Additionally, Section 2 addresses the estate tax treatment of land under a qualified conservation easement. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection regarding estate tax with respect to land under a qualified conservation easement. If the executor elects, the value of such land can be excluded from the gross estate. The new subsection in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the exclusion of the value of land under a qualified conservation easement from the gross estate, subject to certain conditions. The new subsection in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the exclusion of land within a metropolitan area or national park from the gross estate if certain conditions are met, including ownership by the decedent or their family for the past 3 years. The new subsection in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the exclusion of land within a metropolitan area or national park from the gross estate if certain conditions are met, including ownership by the decedent or their family for the past 3 years. Certain contributions related to qualified conservation contributions are also considered for exclusion. The new subsection in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the exclusion of land within a metropolitan area or national park from the gross estate if certain conditions are met, including ownership by the decedent or their family for the past 3 years. Qualified conservation contributions are also considered for exclusion without regard to certain clauses. An additional estate tax is imposed on the first person disposing of property after the decedent's death, based on the increase in estate tax liability due to the value of the development right. The estate tax is imposed on the person disposing of property after the decedent's death, based on the increase in tax liability due to the value of the development right. If only a portion of the property is disposed of, the person must pay a pro rata portion of the tax. The estate tax is due by April 15 of the year following the property disposition. A development right refers to the right to establish or use any structure. The estate tax is due by April 15 of the year following the property disposition. A development right allows for the establishment of structures for commercial purposes or farming activities on the land. The election for land subject to a qualified conservation easement must be made on the tax return and is irrevocable. The executor must calculate the additional estate tax due when making this election. The executor must file a 'Notice of Potential Estate Tax Due' in the locality where the land with a qualified conservation easement is located. The filing must be done as prescribed by the Secretary. Carryover Basis rules under Section 1014(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 apply. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new paragraph regarding the basis of property excluded from the gross estate of a decedent. These amendments apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 1992, including land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after that date. SEC. 3. Gift tax on land with a qualified conservation easement. Gift Tax With Respect to Land Subject to a Qualified Conservation Easement: The transfer of land with a qualified conservation easement may not be considered a taxable gift under the Internal Revenue Code. The additional gift tax is imposed on the first person disposing of property subject to retained development rights after the gift is made. The additional gift tax is imposed on the first person disposing of property subject to retained development rights after the gift is made. The tax amount is based on the increase in gift tax liability if the value of the development right had been treated as a gift. The term "development right" is defined as per section 2031(c)(3)(C). The amendments made by this section apply to gifts of land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after December 31, 1992, with 'donor' substituted for 'executor' in certain sections. SEC. 4. Qualified conservation contribution for land with separated surface and mineral rights. Section 170(h)(5)(B)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a special rule for contributions of property with separated surface and mineral rights. The amendment applies to cases where the likelihood of surface mining on the property is extremely low. The amendment made by this section applies to contributions made after December 31, 1992, in taxable years ending after that date. SEC. 5. Qualified conservation contribution is not a disposition. Qualified conservation contribution by gift or otherwise shall not be treated as a disposition for purposes of the Internal Revenue Code. This applies to qualified real property subject to a conservation easement. The amendments to section 2032A of the Internal Revenue Code state that land under a qualified conservation easement is not disqualified as qualified real property. These changes apply to estates of decedents who passed away after December 31, 1992, and include land with qualified conservation easements granted after that date. Land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after December 31, 1992 is included.
